column4: I want install ubuntu on my laptop, then create a virtual win7 (for work reasons)... what's the best route for this?  Should I create the image off the restore partition on the laptop, or is there a way to use the ubuntu installer, then create an kvm image off the shrunk windows 7 partition, then delete that partition?
I do have a legit win7 license... am I going to have to go some heinous route with it all?

restore from restore partition will overwrite your ubuntu and using the shrinked win7 partition in a VM won't work since the hardware will have changed too much (and kvm is the wrong thing to run virtualized windows anyways)
hmmm... well, they use kvm at the place I work, so I'll have to make it work...
what will virtualbox do over kvm (I'll have to convince my boss on why I don't want to use kvm?
virtualbox integrates a lot lot better into your ubuntu. remember: you virtualize a desktop OS
ok.  I'm assuming one can only really virtualize a dektop OS, unless I were running some sort of hypervisor
what do you need to run on windows?
It's to test stuff on windows, since that's partly what the company does... and I have to make sure it works,
I definitely, tragically, need a win7 vm if I want to work in ubuntu
I totally wouldn't even mess with win7 if I didn't have to
and they're all into kvm, so I'm going to have to make it work, alas
sad to find out it'll be tough, but oh well
